content.webTitle: Doubts over move to cut red tape

fields.headline: Doubts over move to cut red tape
fields.bodyText: The Conservatives accused Gordon Brown yesterday of adding to the red tape on business each year in spite of promises to cut it. George Osborne, shadow chancellor, said: "Every year Gordon Brown promises to cut red tape on business and every year he increases it. British businesses saddled with £40bn of extra regulation under Labour will be very sceptical." He was reacting to an announcement from Mr Brown of his aim to introduce bills to reduce form-filling for firms and cutting business regulators from 29 to seven. "So while some of the proposals he's put forward are welcome - indeed, many come straight from the Conservative manifesto - we will see whether anything in reality actually happens," Mr Osborne said. John Cridland, the CBI deputy director general, said he was keen to see whether Mr Brown delivered. "[We] will judge its success on the quality of future dealings with the new 'improved' version."
